title: With Possible U.S. Economic Downturn on the Horizon, It Pays to Take Out a Mortgage
text:
Mortgage interest rates are at a three-year low, and economists predict they will drop even further by the end of the year. Nikada / Getty Images

Economists are forecasting an economic downturn on the horizon in the U.S. One major indicator is that the wealthy are cutting back on their spending on luxury goods, from cars to art to real estate. In New York City, for instance, one in four new luxury apartments remains unsold, for a total of about 4,100 high-end condos sitting empty.



“There is a chance of there being a recession next year—it’s not a low risk, it’s a very tangible risk,” said Daryl Fairweather, chief economist with Redfin. “People should be thinking through the worst-case scenario and make sure they have an emergency fund.”



Given these concerns, buyers at the high end may find it makes sense to take out a mortgage, even if they currently have the cash for a purchase on hand.



Mortgage interest rates are at a three-year low, and economists predict they will drop even further by the end of the year. The affordability of borrowing makes financing a home purchase a smart strategy for wealthy buyers who want to protect their savings in the event of a recession.

More: For Foreign House Hunters in London, the Time to Act Is Now

Other buyers at the high-end may opt for a mortgage because they plan to invest their wealth elsewhere.



“Buyers are taking out mortgages because their money can make them more money elsewhere,” said Shari Scharfer Rollins, a broker with Douglas Elliman in New York. “With interest rates so low, and no anticipation of them rising, they can earn money from other investments.”



When deciding whether to borrow, buyers must consider what their plans are for their home purchase, factoring in whether it will be a primary or secondary residence or an investment property, what type of mortgage would be the best fit, and which tax deductions they could take.



They must also weigh the risks of buying now, and look at which markets could be hardest hit should a recession come to pass.

Still, experts say, there are rewards that come from taking a chance at a time like this.



More: Whisper Listings Can Mean Deals to Buyers, but Most Benefits Go to the Seller

“It’s very rare to hear a story about someone buying an apartment at the height of the market and making a lot of money,” said Elizabeth Ann Stribling-Kivlan, senior managing director of real estate at Compass in New York. “Fortunes are made when no one else is willing to take the risk.”



Market Indicators of a Looming Economic Downturn



Many Americans are concerned that an economic downturn is imminent; according to a recent Gallup poll, 49% of respondents predicted a recession in the coming year.



But broadly speaking, the economy is strong, with indicators like consumer spending on the rise in recent months.



“The U.S. economy is driven by consumer spending, and based on that, consumer optimism is high, with Americans spending more on things like cars and vacations,” said George Ratiu, senior economist for realtor.com. “There’s a strong demand for housing, employment is solid, and wages are going up. The economy is on very solid footing.”



The recession concerns are originating in the financial sector, where investor confidence is waning amid the Federal Reserve taking actions like cutting interest rates and pumping money into overnight markets. Wealthy buyers, who tend to follow these fluctuations closely, are responding in kind, which is bringing luxury consumption down.

“We’re seeing central banks taking strong steps toward an accommodating policy, with low interest rates,” Mr. Ratiu said. “Luxury buyers are responding quickly to perceived changes, and I do see a slowdown at the upper end of the market. There’s a lot of uncertainty, and the horizon is getting cloudy.”



Another indicator worrying investors is the inversion of the bond yield curve, a shift that has come before every recession since 1955. A survey of American CFOs found that two-thirds expect a recession by the end of next year.



“In this instance, the luxury market is a good reflection of what’s happening in the finance market,” Ms. Fairweather said. “The luxury market has started to slow down, relative to more affordable homes.”



But these jitters in the financial sector could benefit home buyers interested in taking out a mortgage and instead investing some of their cash elsewhere, or keeping some liquidity free.

More: Rising Rents, Wary Buyers Means Now Might Be the Time to Buy an Investment Property

When Taking Out a Mortgage Makes Sense



Luxury buyers who are deciding between paying cash up front for a home and taking out a mortgage must weigh a number of factors, including their plans for the property, the tax incentives of financing, and the market in which they’re buying.



Just as important is the question of how they might invest their cash if they don’t put it into a home.



“Think about whether you’re going to need that money or not if a recession happens,” Ms. Fairweather said. “Do you think your job could be at risk? If you’re paid in stock, could your compensation go down if the stock goes down? If yes, keep the cash on hand and don’t put it into a home.”



For many buyers, it’s about calculating where their money is likeliest to grow. According to the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, the growth of average national home prices have slowed, showing no increase from June to July; in the luxury sector, the average price of a home recently fell by 1.6%.

More: For a Safer Bet in a Tough Luxury Market, Consider the Penthouse

Given the lack of strong appreciation of real estate, taking out a mortgage and investing elsewhere—like stocks or treasuries could be a smart move.



Another compelling reason to opt for a mortgage is the currently low interest rates. Today’s interest rates—particularly a five-year ARM, which has an average 3.49% interest rate, down from 3.92% last year—are favorable to buyers who intend to hold onto a new home purchase for several years.



“If you’re planning to stay five to seven years, assuming your income remains the same, it could make sense to get a mortgage because there’s a low interest rate that’s not likely to go up,” Mr. Ratiu said. “You have the option of taking the cash on hand and investing it in some income or dividend-producing investments.”



On the other hand, he pointed out, some buyers prefer the peace of mind that in the event of a recession, their homes are paid off and they’re only responsible for property taxes and maintenance costs.

More: Amid Political Changes, Buyers Would Be Wise to Consider Prime Central London

Another consideration is whether buyers are planning to purchase a primary or secondary residence, or an investment property.



“If you think you’re going to stay in the home long-term, there’s a better argument for putting money into the home,” Ms. Fairweather said. “You have a guaranteed promise of not paying the interest on a mortgage every month.”



Buyers should keep in mind that they can take a mortgage interest tax deduction on a loan up to $750,000 for a primary residence; for an investment property, they’re entitled to a mortgage interest deduction as well as potential deductions on rental income, property depreciation, and more.



“If you’re buying as an investment, it pays to take financing,” Ms. Cohn said. “The mortgage interest deduction is that much more valuable.”



More: Forget Perfectly Timing the Market and Focus on What You Can Do Instead

Experts predict that some markets will be much harder hit than others in the next recession. Miami and San Diego, for instance, face a higher risk of a housing downturn, according to Redfin. Home prices in these markets are more volatile relative to other cities and there is more investor activity, putting pressure on local homeowners to take out bigger loans.

This means buyers have to decide whether they will risk purchasing in these areas at all. Those who are making a long-term investment are much likelier to see it pay off, even if a recession does come to pass.



“It’s a question of what’s the most important thing to you. Are you trying to grow some cash, or preserve it?” Ms. Stribling-Kivlan said. “Especially in New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco, there’s going to be a point where you just can’t build anymore, and homeowners hold onto things. If you look at the great real estate wealth made in this country, it’s families holding onto properties for generations.”
